description:
Astronomical data (whether images on the sky, or other data) are
typically stored with information about their corresponding projection
(Gnomonic, Mercator, Conical, Aitoff, and *many* more) and coordinate
system (Equatorial, Galactic, Ecliptic, and so on).

I will present `WCSAxes <https://github.com/astrofrog/wcsaxes>`__, a new
framework for plotting such astronomical data, developed as part of the
`Astropy <http://www.astropy.org>`__ project. WCSAxes consists primarily
of a `Matplotlib <http://www.matplotlib.org>`__ Axes sub-class that
seamlessly handles the plotting of ticks, tick labels, and grid lines
for arbitrary coordinate systems and projections.

As an example, the following plot was produced with WCSAxes:

.. figure:: http://www.mpia.de/~robitaille/chandra_avm_small.png
   :alt: The Galactic center as seen by the Chandra X-ray observatory

   The Galactic Center as seen by Chandra

(Image Credit: NASA/CXC/UMass/D. Wang et al. -
http://chandra.harvard.edu/photo/2009/gcenter/)

Since it is a sub-class of the Matplotlib Axes class, all the default
Matplotlib methods such as plot, scatter, imshow, contour, as well as
patches, lines, collections, and so on are supported, and WCSAxes - in
combination with Matplotlib's ability to accept arbitrary
transformations - makes it very easy to define whether the plotting
should apply to pixel coordinates, or a world coordinate system related
to the data.

WCSAxes has been designed as a framework that can be easily used in
other Python tools, and it is planned for inclusion in
`Glue <http://www.glueviz.org>`__, `APLpy <http://aplpy.github.io>`__,
and other astronomical tools. While originally written for Astronomical
images, it should be easily extendable to any kind of map (such as
Earth-based geospatial data) provided that the projection and coordinate
system can be represented by a pixel-to-world transformation.

title: WCSAxes: A Framework for Plotting Astronomical and Geospatial Data
